discussion.content: How can i tell from the question that the hard disk are set up in a raid configuration?

questions.question_text: An end user's laptop has a USB mouse connected. The user removes the USB mouse to pack up at the end of the work day. Before shutting down, the user tries to check a document but finds the built-in peripherals no longer work. Which of the following would BEST resolve this issue?

choices.A: Check the keyboard layout in Settings.
choices.D: Check that the function key is not stuck.

discussion.content: Wouldn't it be quicker to check if the key is stuck?

comments.content:
The way I see it is that they are talking about the "mouse" being unplugged right. The user wants to check a document but finds the "built-in peripherals no longer work". Since the user wants to check a document but now doesn't have their USB mouse connected to move the cursor - the next best thing is the "built-in peripherals" which would be the touch-pad (they stated the user uses a laptop) used to control the cursor.

The function key being stuck has nothing to do with trying to get to the document - which requires a cursor and clicking and maybe the windows button and E as a shortcut to get to the File explorer. besides that, it's cursor movement and clicking.

Hope this makes helps and makes sense to you as this is what led me to the answer B.

questions.question_text: A technician is building a workstation with 8GB of RAM that will host a VM. The VM will be used to test software installations prior to mass deployment. The workstation will also serve the installation files and packages necessary to install applications remotely on networked devices that have passed the testing process. Which of the following hardware components are needed for the setup to function as required? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: A and D. Most of the questions regarding virtualization CompTIA wants you to add more RAM, but 8GB of RAM will be enough for one VM and serving some files. Old CPUs possibly don't support virtualization, which is necessary in this case.

CPU virtualization support, i believe,is about hardware.
if yr cpu dosent support virtualisation, you not gonna need an extra ram

discussion.content: Nah, the answers are A and D. You can't host virtual machines without virtualization support on your CPU.

I Also Think 8GB Of RAM Would Suffice For The Work Mentioned Here But Since The Remaining Option Would Become "Single-Core CPU" Then I Think The Only Answers That Makes Sense Is A & E.
